articles.headline: Unicorns Hunt for Talent Among Silicon Valley’s Giants
articles.snippet: Unicorns, start-ups like Uber and Airbnb valued at $1 billion or more, are hiring people from the likes of Google, especially in fields like mapping.
articles.abstract: Unicorns, start-ups like Uber and Airbnb valued at $1 billion or more, are hiring people from the likes of Google, especially in fields like mapping.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last year, Google’s work force has increasingly been under attack from a herd of unicorns.

articles.headline: Promontory Financial Settles With New York Regulator
articles.snippet: The firm agrees to admit that its actions on behalf of the British bank Standard Chartered did not meet current consulting requirements.
articles.abstract: The firm agrees to admit that its actions on behalf of the British bank Standard Chartered did not meet current consulting requirements.
articles.lead_paragraph: When New York State’s financial regulator challenged the independence of a top Wall Street consultant, the Promontory Financial Group, the firm threatened to sue, vowing to “litigate the matter and defend our firm against this regulatory overreach.”
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Bank of New York Mellon Settles Bribery Case Over Interns
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused the bank of doling out three internships to appease officials at a Middle Eastern sovereign wealth fund.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused the bank of doling out three internships to appease officials at a Middle Eastern sovereign wealth fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: The three interns at Bank of New York Mellon who joined the firm in the summer of 2010 seemed unusual choices on paper. None met the financial giant’s rigorous criteria, and none were hired through the usual internship programs.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: F.D.A. Approves Addyi, a Libido Pill for Women
articles.snippet: The drug has faced criticism from those who say the F.D.A. was pressured. But advocates say the move was long overdue, given the options available to men.
articles.abstract: The drug has faced criticism from those who say the F.D.A. was pressured. But advocates say the move was long overdue, given the options available to men.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first prescription drug to enhance women’s sexual drive won regulatory approval on Tuesday, clinching a victory for a lobbying campaign that had accused the Food and Drug Administration of gender bias for ignoring the sexual needs of women.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Paints Republicans Into Corner With Hispanics
articles.snippet: Several of Donald J. Trump’s rivals are matching his anti-immigrant language, which could again cost the Republicans with Hispanic voters.
articles.abstract: Several of Donald J. Trump’s rivals are matching his anti-immigrant language, which could again cost the Republicans with Hispanic voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans thought they had learned a lesson after 2012: Turning off Latino voters ensures defeat in the general election.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Julia Preston

articles.headline: One Palestinian’s Refusal to Eat Puts Israel in a Bind
articles.snippet: The case has received extraordinary attention because it unfolded as Israel passed a law concerning the force-feeding of hunger strikers.
articles.abstract: The case has received extraordinary attention because it unfolded as Israel passed a law concerning the force-feeding of hunger strikers.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A single Palestinian prisoner’s determination to starve himself to death unless he is freed is flummoxing Israel’s legal, medical, political and security systems.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Diaa Hadid

articles.headline: Ad Blockers and the Nuisance at the Heart of the Modern Web
articles.snippet: The adoption of ad-blocking technology is rising steeply. Some see an existential threat to online content as we know it, but others see a new business niche.
articles.abstract: The adoption of ad-blocking technology is rising steeply. Some see an existential threat to online content as we know it, but others see a new business niche.
articles.lead_paragraph: The great philosopher Homer Simpson once memorably described alcohol as “the cause of and solution to all of life’s problems.” Internet advertising is a bit like that — the funder of and terrible nuisance baked into everything you do online.

articles.headline: Longtime Critic of Modi Is Now a Target
articles.snippet: Teesta Setalvad, who seeks to hold the Indian prime minister responsible for deadly riots in 2002, has been overwhelmed by attacks emanating from entities controlled by him or his allies.
articles.abstract: Teesta Setalvad, who seeks to hold the Indian prime minister responsible for deadly riots in 2002, has been overwhelmed by attacks emanating from entities controlled by him or his allies.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — One of India’s best-known human rights activists, Teesta Setalvad, was brewing her morning tea on July 14 when she got a telephone call from her security guard.

articles.headline: Losing Water, California Tries to Stay Atop Economic Wave
articles.snippet: Despite the drought, communities are pushing ahead with plans for new housing, with advocates saying there will be enough water to meet the demand.
articles.abstract: Despite the drought, communities are pushing ahead with plans for new housing, with advocates saying there will be enough water to meet the demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOLSOM, Calif. — Evert W. Palmer has a vision for this city famous for its state prison: 10,200 new homes spread across the rolling hills to the south, bringing in a flood of new jobs, new business and 25,000 more people.

articles.headline: Syrian Expert Who Shielded Palmyra Antiquities Meets a Grisly Death at ISIS’ Hands
articles.snippet: The body of Khalid al-Asaad, the city’s retired director of antiquities, was hung from a Roman column, the state news media and an activist group said.
articles.abstract: The body of Khalid al-Asaad, the city’s retired director of antiquities, was hung from a Roman column, the state news media and an activist group said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For decades, he was the bespectacled caretaker of some of Syria’s greatest archaeological treasures. He explored the sprawling ruins in his hometown, named a daughter Zenobia after its ancient queen, and became so intertwined with its development that one historian called him “Mr. Palmyra.”

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton, Pressed on Race, Issues Her Own Challenge
articles.snippet: In an exchange with an activist from Black Lives Matter, a candidate who has advocated civil rights for decades shows passion mixed with practicality.
articles.abstract: In an exchange with an activist from Black Lives Matter, a candidate who has advocated civil rights for decades shows passion mixed with practicality.
articles.lead_paragraph: The video is visceral and raw: Hillary Rodham Clinton — the presidential candidate so often faulted for insulating herself from voters and critics alike — in a tense, awkward, unscripted moment.
